DEATHBED REPENTANCE
With this issue the seniors on THE NEWS-LETTER retire as
gracefully as possible to private life. From now on they can loaf
with a clear conscience, a thing that not all of them could completely achieve, to speak from personal experience, while posts of
responsibility weighed upon their souls.
In former years editorial swan songs have impressed us as'
perfunctory expressions sometimes a trifle forced. Now, however,
we see the error of our ways. It is with an unmistakable feeling
of regret that we sever our connections with the NEWS-LETTER and
with the men on its staff. From a more impersonal viewpoint it
is fortunate that our four years' fling at journalism, if we may
give our activities a term of that dignity, has come .to a close.
Whatever contributions we may have had to offer have been long
since made. In that light it is a pleasure to turn the reins over to
new leaders, eager, optimistic, and capable. We are proud of our
successors.
We were once in the same boat ourselves, or imagined ourselves so. A year ago we were supremely confident that we could,
write, and our head literally teemed with policies and constructive
suggestion.
Even the most rapid glance over the year's editorials has completely dispelled the first illusion; our constructive policy seems to
have dwindled to incidental fault finding with nearly everything
on the campus which came across our path.
It is this which, on our positively last public appearance, worries us. We still contend that most of our criticisms were just;
and we even hope that they have done some good. But if we have
left an impression that in scholastic standards, student affairs, or
general spirit the university, is weak, we are sorry. Hopkins is
our university. Viewed from every angle we love it and we are
proud of it. We have pride in its past and present, and absolute
faith in its future.

Psychology of sob-stuff! There are times when I forget to
be critical, and become more facile clay than the most easily buffaloed of Bryn Mawr school-girls. ... Went to see "Beau Geste"
the other night, a movie which, if I had held intact my pretense
of critical aloofness, I could never have been led to attend. Somehow, I needed to express sincerely my own shameful romanticism
—so I went.
Such pathos! An inexcusable piece of tragic and impossible
melodrama—if you are critical—based on the remarkably sentimental affection of three brothers. If I, along with several other
males and innumerable females, represent the mob, "Beau Geste"
was a success. We had all wept in a varying degree when the
lights came on. Not much—I wept far more copiously at "Broken
Blossoms"—but enough to make the, chewing of a handkerchief
and the ruination of ten finger-nails necessary for the prevention
of audible sobs. And simply because two rather able movie actors
pretended to die.
Personally, I never made vows of eternal friendship and
loyalty with the friends of my infancy;—our pursuits were of a
less mentionable nature—nor have I ever heard of the consummation of such vows in real life; but the Geste brothers made them,
and what's more, kept 'em; remembered them in the very presence
of death. It is not, then, truth which the mob (and I) love. It is
always the ideal rather than the real which wins the acclaim of
the uncultured, and in many instances, may I note, of the cultured
as well. Michael Geste is no more a myth than Homer's brainchild, Achilles.
What soul is there, I wonder, even in the most critical of us,
which does not contain this absurd and divine love of things as
they are not; of qualities far too fine for humanity to possess?
Only the soul that knows no day-dreams. "Beau Geste" symbolizes, in a faintly maudlin fashion, it is true, this reaching for
a moon of impossible radiance, this love of nonexistent characters
cut from the cloth that dreams are made of, this crying need of
every man of a bolster for his conceit. Hero-worship,... idolatry
. . . what you will;—there is a niche in the gallery of mankind's
idols which must be filled by the ideal man, the man dying the
ideal death. If Cabell's definition is true, and if "the signal function of art is to prevaricate beautifully about mankind," then "Beau
Geste" is art, because oh, how it prevaricates!
. . . And, if it is excusable to express one's own romanticisms,
as well as to appreciate those of Percival Wrenn....
Oft in the emptiness of night,
I lie awake and hear the breath of one
Who is not there;
See dim the profile in the wisp of light,
And smell Spring's fragrance in the silken hair.
And while the heartless night roars onward in my ears
I murmur wordless passions to my soul
Take s-olace in the silencing of tears
And start—and find there's no one there.

DEATHBED REPENTANCE
With this issue the seniors on THE NEWS-LETTER retire as
gracefully as possible to private life. From now on they can loaf
with a clear conscience, a thing that not all of them could completely achieve, to speak from personal experience, while posts of
responsibility weighed upon their souls.
In former years editorial swan songs have impressed us as'
perfunctory expressions sometimes a trifle forced. Now, however,
we see the error of our ways. It is with an unmistakable feeling
of regret that we sever our connections with the NEWS-LETTER and
with the men on its staff. From a more impersonal viewpoint it
is fortunate that our four years' fling at journalism, if we may
give our activities a term of that dignity, has come .to a close.
Whatever contributions we may have had to offer have been long
since made. In that light it is a pleasure to turn the reins over to
new leaders, eager, optimistic, and capable. We are proud of our
successors.
We were once in the same boat ourselves, or imagined ourselves so. A year ago we were supremely confident that we could,
write, and our head literally teemed with policies and constructive
suggestion.
Even the most rapid glance over the year's editorials has completely dispelled the first illusion; our constructive policy seems to
have dwindled to incidental fault finding with nearly everything
on the campus which came across our path.
It is this which, on our positively last public appearance, worries us. We still contend that most of our criticisms were just;
and we even hope that they have done some good. But if we have
left an impression that in scholastic standards, student affairs, or
general spirit the university, is weak, we are sorry. Hopkins is
our university. Viewed from every angle we love it and we are
proud of it. We have pride in its past and present, and absolute
faith in its future.

Psychology of sob-stuff! There are times when I forget to
be critical, and become more facile clay than the most easily buffaloed of Bryn Mawr school-girls. ... Went to see "Beau Geste"
the other night, a movie which, if I had held intact my pretense
of critical aloofness, I could never have been led to attend. Somehow, I needed to express sincerely my own shameful romanticism
—so I went.
Such pathos! An inexcusable piece of tragic and impossible
melodrama—if you are critical—based on the remarkably sentimental affection of three brothers. If I, along with several other
males and innumerable females, represent the mob, "Beau Geste"
was a success. We had all wept in a varying degree when the
lights came on. Not much—I wept far more copiously at "Broken
Blossoms"—but enough to make the, chewing of a handkerchief
and the ruination of ten finger-nails necessary for the prevention
of audible sobs. And simply because two rather able movie actors
pretended to die.
Personally, I never made vows of eternal friendship and
loyalty with the friends of my infancy;—our pursuits were of a
less mentionable nature—nor have I ever heard of the consummation of such vows in real life; but the Geste brothers made them,
and what's more, kept 'em; remembered them in the very presence
of death. It is not, then, truth which the mob (and I) love. It is
always the ideal rather than the real which wins the acclaim of
the uncultured, and in many instances, may I note, of the cultured
as well. Michael Geste is no more a myth than Homer's brainchild, Achilles.
What soul is there, I wonder, even in the most critical of us,
which does not contain this absurd and divine love of things as
they are not; of qualities far too fine for humanity to possess?
Only the soul that knows no day-dreams. "Beau Geste" symbolizes, in a faintly maudlin fashion, it is true, this reaching for
a moon of impossible radiance, this love of nonexistent characters
cut from the cloth that dreams are made of, this crying need of
every man of a bolster for his conceit. Hero-worship,... idolatry
. . . what you will;—there is a niche in the gallery of mankind's
idols which must be filled by the ideal man, the man dying the
ideal death. If Cabell's definition is true, and if "the signal function of art is to prevaricate beautifully about mankind," then "Beau
Geste" is art, because oh, how it prevaricates!
. . . And, if it is excusable to express one's own romanticisms,
as well as to appreciate those of Percival Wrenn....
Oft in the emptiness of night,
I lie awake and hear the breath of one
Who is not there;
See dim the profile in the wisp of light,
And smell Spring's fragrance in the silken hair.
And while the heartless night roars onward in my ears
I murmur wordless passions to my soul
Take s-olace in the silencing of tears
And start—and find there's no one there.
